awd_titl_txt: EPAS/AIS Collaborative Research: Adaptive Design for Controllability of a System of Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicle Charging Stations
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop a method for integrating design and power management of a regional system for deployment of plug-in electric vehicle charging stations, each of which obtains power from wind, solar and the grid. The method embodies a two-stage algorithm, the first stage handles system design, and the second stage handles dynamic control under uncertainty.  The second stage control problem is embedded within the first stage design problem, thus enabling design for controllability. The solution procedure uses a new, statistically parsimonious algorithm to reduce the computational demands that have previously made this problem intractable. 

Intellectual Merit
This research is foundational to energy system development, an area of critical national need. Success in addressing the foundational issues will demonstrate the efficacy of the method for the design and deployment of realistic systems and help identify questions worthy of further investigation. 

Broader Impacts
This work has the potential of improving the penetration level of renewable energy and ease or delay the need for infrastructure improvement. Design for controllability is critical for many other complex systems in energy, transportation, telecommunications, sustainability, manufacturing, health care, etc. The team has a track record of educating members of under-represented groups and will continue to do so. Research results will be disseminated via standard academic means and will be shared with Vision North Texas, a public-private partnership seeking a more sustainable future for North Central Texas.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Given the importance of reducing carbon emissions, we developed a method of integrating the design and control of a system of charging stations for plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) charging stations. These charging stations obtain electricity from solar power, wind power and the grid. A large part of the successful design of these systems requires the understanding and modeling of uncertainties due the variation in wind power, solar power, the market price of electricity, and customer demand. Although historical data and trends have been used to the extent possible, there are many uncertainties in this problem which are not well understood; they are modeled flexibly to enable exploration of decisions under various levels of uncertainty.

With our collaborators at the University of Texas at Arlington, we developed a framework for designing these systems to be dynamically controlled – this is in contrast to the current practice which usually involves first designing the system itself and then designing how it can be controlled. By integrating the design of the system and its control, it is possible to deliver more accurately designed system performance. This is a very large problem to solve computationally.  We modularize it using a two-stage framework. The design problem is modeled as the first stage master problem, and the dynamic control problem is modeled as the second stage sub-problem. We formulated the first stage master problem using the compromise Decision Support Problem (cDSP) a metaheuristic construct based on mathematical programming and goal programming; using the cDSP approach allows relatively rapid computability. The developed method is applicable to both original design in which a system is first developed and also to the design of a modification to an existing system. This method has been used to obtain preliminary results for the optimization of more general networks such as supply chains. For each possible system design stage, the control design stage problem is solved.  Our collaborators at the University of Texas at Arlington developed the control design stage of the problem (see their report for further information). The calculated responses they developed together with additional input data are used to construct a surrogate model based on DACE, the Design and Analysis of Computer Experiments. This enables rapid computation. The example application is a system of PHEV charging stations for the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex to be incremented sequentially over the years 2014-2016.

A further advantage of this approach is its modularity which allows convenient modification of individual simulations as more information becomes available. Also this allows a designer to rapidly explore options to determine the effects of budget modifications, changes in demand over time, and the effects of various other uncertainties. Further, our proposed approach allows the incremental development of the systems of charging stations which has the dual advantage of allowing system modification over time if the anticipated conditions change as the system develops. Further, this approach allows incremental investment in the project and the prospect of early return on the investment. 

The broader impact of this work included our intent to work with Vision North Texas, a community/government/academic organization whose objective was to understand the options for growth in the region.  Unfortunately during the course of our project, Vision North Texas became very much less active and we have been unable to meet this objective. Other broader impacts of this work include educating students and publication and presentation of the wo...
por.por_txt_cntn:
Given the importance of reducing carbon emissions, we developed a method of integrating the design and control of a system of charging stations for plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) charging stations. These charging stations obtain electricity from solar power, wind power and the grid. A large part of the successful design of these systems requires the understanding and modeling of uncertainties due the variation in wind power, solar power, the market price of electricity, and customer demand. Although historical data and trends have been used to the extent possible, there are many uncertainties in this problem which are not well understood; they are modeled flexibly to enable exploration of decisions under various levels of uncertainty.

With our collaborators at the University of Texas at Arlington, we developed a framework for designing these systems to be dynamically controlled – this is in contrast to the current practice which usually involves first designing the system itself and then designing how it can be controlled. By integrating the design of the system and its control, it is possible to deliver more accurately designed system performance. This is a very large problem to solve computationally.  We modularize it using a two-stage framework. The design problem is modeled as the first stage master problem, and the dynamic control problem is modeled as the second stage sub-problem. We formulated the first stage master problem using the compromise Decision Support Problem (cDSP) a metaheuristic construct based on mathematical programming and goal programming; using the cDSP approach allows relatively rapid computability. The developed method is applicable to both original design in which a system is first developed and also to the design of a modification to an existing system. This method has been used to obtain preliminary results for the optimization of more general networks such as supply chains. For each possible system design stage, the control design stage problem is solved.  Our collaborators at the University of Texas at Arlington developed the control design stage of the problem (see their report for further information). The calculated responses they developed together with additional input data are used to construct a surrogate model based on DACE, the Design and Analysis of Computer Experiments. This enables rapid computation. The example application is a system of PHEV charging stations for the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex to be incremented sequentially over the years 2014-2016.

A further advantage of this approach is its modularity which allows convenient modification of individual simulations as more information becomes available. Also this allows a designer to rapidly explore options to determine the effects of budget modifications, changes in demand over time, and the effects of various other uncertainties. Further, our proposed approach allows the incremental development of the systems of charging stations which has the dual advantage of allowing system modification over time if the anticipated conditions change as the system develops. Further, this approach allows incremental investment in the project and the prospect of early return on the investment. 

The broader impact of this work included our intent to work with Vision North Texas, a community/government/academic organization whose objective was to understand the options for growth in the region.  Unfortunately during the course of our project, Vision North Texas became very much less active and we have been unable to meet this objective. Other broader impacts of this work include educating students and publication and presentation of the work.  Two PhD students were supported in part by this funding, material was provided for an MS project and four undergraduate research projects. Five journal articles related to this work have been written and are in various stages of the publication process.  Six conference papers/presentations ...
